Key Arguments: The legislation sacrifices tangible freedoms for a perceived safety.
Free market of ideas should allow misinformation to be naturally filtered out.
Censorship could prevent the emergence of new, potentially groundbreaking ideas.
Government and big tech collusion threatens democratic ideals.
Historical examples show that censorship often aligns with oppressive regimes.
The legislation could lead to overreach in controlling speech on various societal issues.
Notable Quotes: Have we lost our sense of proportion when measuring prudence and fear, and whether we are sacrificing tangible freedoms for a spectral safety?
History has shown that censorship has evoked as much harm and damage than any campaign of misinformation has ever done.

Censorship only curtails scientific understandings and advancement, if lessons from many great scientists and discoveries demonstrate, from Galileo to Dr Ignaz Semmelweis to the aforementioned, Dr Marshall.
Fear cannot be a foundation of moral and political argument and that the necessary antidote to the toxin of fear is a wholehearted embrace of the principles of freedom, equality and co-operation.
